results.title: Rome
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Practical guide to Europe”.
Presented by John Guerrasio, this is an ideal video for intending travelers to Rome (or Italy generally). Tips and practical advice is given as to accommodation, transportation, places to eat, historical sites to visit, seasonal times to avoid, and suggestions of where to go and what to do whilst in Rome. Also provides a map pointing out the location of major sight-seeing destinations, what to do and what not to do to in respect of Italian culture and customs, and generally assist you in making your visit to Rome an enjoyable experience.

group_siblings.title: Paris

results.title: Paris
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Practical guide to Europe”.
A practical guide for anyone intending to travel to Paris. Highlights the major cultural attractions, historical districts and shopping precincts. Provides advice on public transport options and locating suitable accommodation. Offers tips on visiting galleries and museums during free or quiet periods. Suggests where to eat and what you should expect to pay. Includes the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre, Disneyland, Fountainbleau and Versailles. Presented by John Guerrasio.

results.title: Alvar Aalto: technology and nature
results.creator_credit: Ywe Yalander, BBC Wales, Oy Yleisradio Ab Svenska TV-enheten and WNYC-TV (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Born in Finland, Alvar Aalto (1898-1976) was one of the greatest architect and industrial designers of the 20th century. As a young man he rejected the ideals of art nouveau movement, preferring instead to follow his interests in functionalism. As a humanitarian he felt that democracy would be achieved by the mechanisation and standardisation of building practices, being the only way to give more to man. He also recognised the paradox of this and was to forever learn from nature, believing it to be the symbol of freedom. His architecture was widely accepted due to his success in marrying nature with art, man and mass production. But for Aalto, it was nature that was the great teacher, and nature that would provide the greatest inspiration to his work. Forever being influenced by the forests and nature broadly, his buildings would echo the elegance and asymmetry that expresses a natural order. Aalto’s humanitarian interests meant that the function of the building was always directed by the needs of the users. This earned Aalto lasting respect for his designs (i.e the Paimio Sanatorium has long been praised as one of the greatest buildings of the 20th Century), providing many humanitarian solutions to architectural problems. Aalto rejected synthetic materials and plastics, calling them, “drugstore architecture”, and preferred to use natural materials such as; wood, brick, stone, glass and ceramic tile. Aalto invested his interest in these materials and design to develop furniture and fittings to complete the interiors of his buildings. Aalto was most known in his industrial design for laminating and bending layers of birchwood to create bent wood furniture, a technique that has come to symbolise his home region.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ywe Yalander, BBC Wales, Oy Yleisradio Ab Svenska TV-enheten and WNYC-TV (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Rock U.S.A. Part 1
results.brief_description: Part one of a two-part series. Presents an overview of rock music throughout America featuring a strange mixture of artists including early footage of Blondie (Debra Harry) and raw and energetic performances by the Dead Boys, Heart, Mother’s Finest and Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes.

results.title: Rock n' roll the greatest years: 1967 volume 2
results.brief_description: Relive some of the great hits of the year 1967, including; “Happy Jack” (The Who), “Autumn almanac” (The Kinks), “Zabadak” (Dave Dee Dozy Beaky Mick & Tich), “San Franciscan nights” (Eric Burdon), “Dedicated to the one I love” (Mamas & Papas), “Respect” (Aretha Franklin), “Mellow yellow” (Donovan), “Hole in my shoe” (Traffic), Soothe me” (Sam & Dave), “I can see for miles” (The Who), “I’m a man (The Spencer Davis Group), “The Wind cries Mary” (Jimi Hendrix experience), “Sweet soul music” (Arthur Conley) and “Creek alley” (Mamas & Papas).

results.title: Romanov
results.creator_credit: Yuri Sokol, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Sokol Films
results.brief_description: The history of the influential royal Romanov family and their descendants search for identity are the subject of this SBS funded documentary. The tape covers present attitudes in Russia towards a monarchy, and follows the story of one Australian Romanov member who, with his wife, returns to Russia to research his heritage.

results.title: Romancing the Stone (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Robert Zemeckis, Michael Douglas, El Corazon Productions and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A best-selling romance writer, played by Kathleen Turner, gets more than bargained for when she goes to Colombia to find her kidnapped sister. There’s a mysterious man hanging around, the jungle is full of hungry crocodiles and the kidnappers are out to get her. Luckily a hero right out of her imagination (Michael Douglas) is there to rescue her…but for a price. This is a film that recalls the spirit of the old movie matinee serials.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Zemeckis, Michael Douglas, El Corazon Productions and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation

results.title: Rock-a-bye
results.creator_credit: Jacques Bensimon, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Popular idols of the rock music scene - The Rolling Stones, The Stampeders, Whiskey Howl, Alice Cooper, Muddy Waters - are seen and heard in this film. It is a penetrating look at the whole pop music sub-culture and what keeps it alive, filmed in Canada, on and off-stage, and behind the scenes at record companies, radio broadcasting studios, and board rooms where hucksters plan the sales campaigns. The film includes personal interviews in which some of the stars explain what it’s all about and features Alice Cooper hacking a doll to pieces on stage. Obscene language has been bleeped out.

results.title: Romancing the stone
results.creator_credit: Robert Zemeckis, Michael Douglas, El Corazon Productions and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Best-selling romance writer Joan Wilder (Kathleen Turner) specialises in stories replete with heroes in white, villains in black and damsels with heaving bosoms. For Joan however the reality is that she has a staid life without true adventures. All that changes when she receives a desperate call from her sister in South America who, having been kidnapped by mercenaries, is desperately in need of rescuing. Joan is in possession of a valuable treasure map, sought after by the police trailing her and the kidnappers who are holding her sister, both of who will stop at nothing to get it. Once in South America Joan falls in with soldier of fortune Jack Holton (Michael Douglas) who happens to be a handsome, dashing hero. Many films followed in the wake of “Raiders of the lost ark”, hoping to mimic the success of that film, but few films managed, as successfully as this one does, to capture the same energy and sense of rollicking, great, Saturday afternoon matinee fun.
